title: BTS, the K-Pop Band, Dives into NFTs to Sell Digital Trading Cards to Fans; Hybe, the entertainment company that manages BTS, says the tradable digital cards will play music
text:
No date was given for when the NFTs will be launched. Representatives for Hybe, the entertainment company that manages BTS, didn't respond to requests for comment.

NFTs, or nonfungible tokens, are digital collectibles that are authenticated using blockchain technology and are usually purchased with cryptocurrencies. They have soared in popularity in recent months, with many celebrities diving into the space. Martha Stewart, for instance, is selling holiday-related digital images and plans to turn a seductive selfie into an NFT.

The new venture for BTS was announced by Hybe in a 51-minute online briefing, where it also unveiled a slew of other projects, including a BTS videogame that is expected to be released in the first half of next year. The company is also looking to recreate in the U.S. the success of Korean pop acts, holding auditions to create a new group made-up of teenage girls.

BTS has become a world-wide phenomenon, topping the charts in the U.S. and getting billions of online views for its music videos. Big companies have taken notice: A BTS meal at McDonald's Corp. helped boost sales at the burger chain earlier this year.

Hybe said it was partnering with the South Korean crypto exchange Dunamu to create the BTS NFTs.

BTS, the K-Pop Band, Dives into NFTs to Sell Digital Trading Cards to Fans
